Body:
Correct me if I misunderstood your question. Assuming that you refer to a fixed combination of morphemes, e.g., fixed root, derivational morphemes, and inflectional morphemes, just as in German nimmst ... mit (as a 2nd person singular present indicative form of mitnehmen lexeme).

What you are talking about seems to be simply word, morphologically unparsed, or word form.
Specifically answering your question, whether word is:

  • an independent lexical unit, independent from the original verb — No:
    • not a lexical unit, since Lexicon deals with Lexemes, not with individual word forms;
    • not an independent one. If you define "independent" is that you can use it independently, you really can do it in only a tiny subset of sentences that require only this particular word form;
  • it has it's own special meaning — One or many, indistinguishable if you really analyze the word alone;
    • Consider English works — it can be either a noun (in plural form), a verb (3rd person singular), or a family name (a proper noun). Even if you stick to verbs, I believe it's easy to find counter-examples in virtually every language;
  • and, unlike other verbs, it's invariable — Yes, it's invariable. However, how can we compare a whole lexeme (a complete set of its forms) and one of its particular word forms?
